bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 22, 1929

div1.p: Carter discusses her work on references and Frost's work on the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever in anticipation of the completed product.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, March 22, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel.
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
March 22, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Your much appreciated letter of March 21st. has just
reached me.

It was good of you to take time to tell me about Dr. Wakeman,
as I was, of course, extremely interested in the matter and much puz-
zled by the newspaper reports of his illness and death. It is indeed
unfortunate for any erroneous data to be published which may, as you
say, make people consider the yellow fever campaign “even more danger-
ous to the personnel than it really is.”

I saw Mrs. Frost, here in Washington, a couple of days ago and
she said that Dr. Frost, or herself, would notify me just as soon as he
had things cleared up for us to work together. No word as yet, but the
week is not over and I am ready to leave whenever I do hear from him.
In the interim, there are, of course, many things that can still be done
over here; in the further simplification and elucidation of the biblio-
graphic cards and in the search for the few references which are still
eluding us. Miss Brown and I worked until 10.30 last night (intended to
stop at 10, but “got on the trail” of one of the most exasperating of
our unverified quotations (no author given) and--luckily--“ran it to
earth” and made out its bibliographic card before we separated. On the
other hand, she has been over 19 volumes of Walckenaer's ..“voyages”
without finding a much-desired reference to “Agra beads” on the Cuinea
Coast. Well, there are 21 vols. in the set, so we may get it yet--still
“two to go!” I looked for it last spring, but didn't dare take too much
time then as I had to verify essentials first.

Like yourself, I “am looking forward in the near future to see-
-2-
see-
ing the completed manuscript,” and this with feelings which none can
better appreciate than yourself, who know what the work meant to both Father
and myself during his life and that its completion has been my one hope and
occupation and preoccupation since his death. It is, as I wrote Dr.
Frost, an unspeakable comfort to realize that, with his resumption of
the final editing, the book, as Father wished it, should now soon be
an accomplished fact.

With very best wishes to yourself and to Dr. and Mrs. Beeuwkes
when next you see them, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
